awd_titl_txt: RUI: Collaborative Research: Mapping and Tracking Conformational Control of Nitric Oxide Synthase Activation
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Carey Johnson from the University of Kansas, Dr. Brian Smith from Medical College of Wisconsin, and Dr. David Arnett from Northwestern College. The project investigates shapes (conformations) and shape changes of the enzyme nitric oxide synthase (NOS). The importance of conformational changes in the function of complex enzymes like NOS has become increasingly recognized. NOS activity requires a sequence of electron transfers between different domains of the enzyme. The hypothesis is that these events are controlled by conformational dynamics. In this project, the conformations and conformational changes of NOS are tracked by time-resolved and single-molecule fluorescence techniques. Mass spectrometry shows how domain interactions are regulated by binding to NOS of a calcium signaling protein, calmodulin. The results may show how multi-domain enzymes function through conformational changes. The project provides training in advanced fluorescence and mass spectrometric techniques for graduate students at Kansas University and the Medical College of Wisconsin. Undergraduate students from all participating institutions are trained in interdisciplinary science research. The project also offers training for members of the UKanTeach program which trains science majors as high school science teachers.

This project exploits the spatial and temporal resolution inherent in time-resolved and single-molecule fluorescence to identify and track the conformational states of nitric oxide synthase (NOS). NOS is a homodimeric enzyme that catalyzes formation of nitric oxide by shuttling electrons from modules in one monomer to the heme in the oxygenase domain of the other. Electron transfer in both domains depends on calmodulin binding. Because electron transfer only occurs when the electron donor and electron acceptor are in close proximity, conformational changes must occur to bring different donor and acceptor couples together sequentially. The time scales of interchange among conformational states are not known, nor is it clear how the observed conformational changes correlate with the catalytic cycle of the enzyme. The methods of the project correlate conformations and dynamics detected by fluorescence with knowledge of inter-domain interactions at the peptide level. These inter-domain interactions are observed from hydrogen-deuterium exchange (HDX) mass spectrometry. To identify and assign conformational states observed, selected site-directed mutants that disrupt specific subdomain interactions are probed by both fluorescence and mass spectrometry. The project may lead to a detailed model of NOS function that describes the conformational sequences and rates of conformational changes. The project may also demonstrate how the conformational sequences are related to enzyme regulation.  The project provides training in advanced fluorescence and mass spectrometric techniques for graduate students at Kansas University and the Medical College of Wisconsin. Undergraduate students from all participating institutions are trained in interdisciplinary science research. The project also offers training for members of the UKanTeach program which trains science majors as high school science teachers.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to detect different conformations of the enzyme neuronal nitric oxide synthase (nNOS). When activated by a smaller calcium signaling protein, calmodulin (CaM), nNOS generates nitric oxide, a molecule important in neurotransmission. The chemical reaction generating nitric oxide requires transfer of electrons from the reductase domain of the enzyme to the heme substrate of the oxygenase domain of a partner nNOS molecule. Electrons typically jump only short distances (a few Ångstroms), whereas the nNOS enzyme as a whole is much larger, comprising several subdomains. The enzyme transfers electrons through a series of steps, starting with electron transfer from a subdomain containing flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) to a subdomain containing flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and then from the FMN subdomain on to the oxygenase domain.

Our goal was to detect the conformational states involved and then to find how fast enzyme conformations change from one to another. Our method used time-resolved and single-molecule fluorescence detection. Calmodulin was labeled with a fluorescent dye (Alexa fluor, AF, or Cy) to enable fluorescence detection.  We measured time-resolved fluorescence decays of labelled CaM (CaM-AF) complexed with nNOS by time-correlated single-photon counting. The fluorescence decayed much faster than for CaM-AF in the absence of nNOS due to energy transfer from dye to the heme of nNOS. Analysis of the fluorescence decay by a maximum entropy method showed at least four decay components. We attribute these to four different conformations that have different fluorescence decay lifetimes because of different efficiencies of energy transfer to heme (see figure). Faster decay is associated with conformations where CaM-AF is close to the heme, slower decay with conformations where CaM-AF is farther from the heme. 

This result raised the question: what are the four conformations of nNOS-CaM-AF? To answer this question, we used a series of site-directed mutants of nNOS and CaM provided by our collaborators. Each of these mutants was chosen to disrupt a specific interaction between subdomains of nNOS. For example, the mutations in nNOS-E762R,E816R,E819R (where the glutamic acid residues at positions 762, 816, and 819 have been changed to arginine), is known to disrupt the interaction between the FMN subdomain and the oxygenase domain. The resulting fluorescence decay is much slower than for nNOS without mutations (see figure). Analysis shows that the two populations with the fastest fluorescence decays are reduced. Hence, we can assign these two populations to conformations where the FMN subdomain interacts with the oxygenase domain. In contrast, the E924R mutation of nNOS disrupts interactions between the FAD and FMN subdomains. The fluorescence decay for CaM-AF complexed with nNOS-E924R are much faster than that for normal (“wild-type”) nNOS. Hence, we can assign the populations with shorter fluorescence lifetimes to conformations where the FAD and FMN subdomain interact.

We carried out similar measurements with site-directed mutants of CaM to determine the role of CaM interactions. Together these measurements provide a picture of the nature of the conformations of nNOS and suggest their role in electron transfer.

These measurements, however, do not tell us how fast the enzyme conformations change. To answer that question, we carried out single-molecule fluorescence measurements by two methods: total-internal-reflection fluorescence (TIRF) microscopy and fluorescence lifetime imaging.  These methods track the fluorescence intensity and fluorescent lifetime from single molecules over a period of seconds.  We observed changes in both fluorescence intensity and lifetime on time scales of milliseconds to seconds, attributable to conformational changes of the enzyme.

As a result of this project, we have a more detailed understanding of the conformational states that allow electron transfer in NOS. The work has identified the key domain interactions involved in the conformational states of nNOS. Single-molecule experiments at both the University of Kansas and at Northwestern College are revealing the rates of interchange among these conformational states.

The project introduced new methods of using fluorescence to detect protein conformations, for example the measurements of fluorescence decays for systematically selected site-directed mutants, the use of a reporter fluorophore to permit ratio measurements in single-molecule TIRF, and tracking fluorescence lifetime throughout a single-molecule trajectory. These methods will be applicable to other enzyme systems that contain heme.

Over the course of this project, a total of some 25 undergraduate students participated in the individualized research projects at Northwestern College. These students gained experience in multi-site, multi-disciplinary research using advanced biochemical and spectroscopic techniques. Four of these students participated in Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) programs at our collaborating institutions – the University of Kansas and the Medical College of Wisconsin.  The project also provided opportunities for several Course Embedded Undergraduate Research Experiences (CURES) in the biochemistry, instrumental analysis, and physical chemistry courses.  Several of these students and have gone on to graduate training, jobs in the biotech industry, or the health professions.
